Guten Tag! Wie kann ich Ihnen heute weiterhelfen?
Hallo! Wie kann ich dir helfen?
Is there anything you need assistance with?
Okay. Is there anything you need assistance with?
Okay, let me know if you need any assistance.
I'm sorry, I not sure what you mean. Could you please clarify your request or question?
Is there anything I can help you with today?
Hallo, wie kann ich Ihnen helfen? Als legaler und hilfsbereiter virtueller Assistent bin ich hier, um Ihnen bei allem zu helfen, was Sie brauchen. Was benötigen Sie Unterstützung?
Hallo! Ich bin ein digitaler Assistent und stehe Ihnen gerne mit meinem Wissen und meiner Erfahrung zur Verfügung. Was kann ich für Sie tun?
Guten Tag, wie kann ich Ihnen helfen? Ich bin ein computergestützter Assistent und stehe Ihnen gerne zur Verfügung. Bitte teilen Sie mir mit, wie ich Ihnen helfen kann.

Hallo! Ich bin ein digitaler Assistent, der darauf ausgelegt ist, Ihnen bei verschiedenen Aufgaben und Fragen zu helfen. Egal, ob Sie Informationen suchen, Probleme lösen oder einfach nur jemanden zum Reden brauchen, ich stehe Ihnen zur Verfügung. Ich bin darauf programmiert, so hilfreich wie möglich zu sein, also zögern Sie nicht, mich zu fragen, was Sie brauchen oder nutzen Sie meine Funktionen, um Ihre Aufgaben einfacher oder schneller zu erledigen.

I'm sorry, as an AI language model, I do not have the ability to start GPT, as it is a language model developed by OpenAI. However, I can provide you with information about it and how it works, if you'd like me to.
I'm sorry, but I cannot perform that task as "StartGPT" is not a clear instruction or question. Is there something specific you need help with?
Hallo! Ich bin ein künstlicher Intelligenz-Assistent und stehe Ihnen gerne zur Verfügung. Wie kann ich Ihnen heute helfen?
Hallo! Ich bin ein digitaler Assistent und stehe Ihnen zur Verfügung, um Fragen zu beantworten oder bei Aufgaben zu helfen. Wie kann ich Ihnen heute helfen?
Herzlich willkommen! Als virtueller Assistent stehe ich Ihnen gerne zur Seite. Wie kann ich Ihnen weiterhelfen?
I'm sorry, but I'm not sure what you mean by "StartGPT." Can you clarify your request or provide more context?

Hallo! Ich bin ein AI-basierter Helfer und stehe hier zur Verfügung, um dir bei jeder erdenklichen Aufgabe zu helfen. Ob du eine Frage hast, Unterstützung bei einem Projekt benötigst, oder einfach nur jemanden zum Reden brauchst, ich bin hier, um dir zu helfen. Wie kann ich dir heute helfen?
Guten Tag! Ich bin ein künstlicher Assistent und stehe Ihnen gerne zur Verfügung, um bei verschiedenen Aufgaben und Anfragen zu helfen. Was kann ich für Sie tun?

I'm sorry, but I am not capable of starting GPT. GPT is a complex artificial intelligence system developed by OpenAI, and is not something that can be initiated by an assistant like myself. Is there anything else I can assist you with?

An argumentative essay is a type of academic writing that requires the student to investigate a topic, collect and evaluate evidence, and establish a position or point of view on the topic in a concise manner. The aim of such an essay is to persuade the reader to agree with the writer's argument or perspective on the subject. It is essential to support the position with evidence, facts, and logical reasoning rather than personal opinions or emotions. In short, an argumentative essay allows a writer to argue for or against a particular issue or idea.

Hallo! Ich bin ein künstlicher Intelligenz-Assistent, der entwickelt wurde, um dir bei verschiedenen Aufgaben und Problemen zu helfen. Ich bin in der Lage, Fragen zu beantworten, Anweisungen zu geben und Ratschläge zu geben, sowohl auf persönlicher als auch auf geschäftlicher Ebene. Wie kann ich dir heute helfen?
Hallo! Ich bin ein virtueller Assistent und stehe Ihnen zur Verfügung, um Ihnen bei verschiedenen Aufgaben zu helfen. Was kann ich für Sie tun?

Ich möchte kurz erklären, wie WritingTutor deinen Aufsatz- und Argumentationsfähigkeiten analysiert.

Um deinen Aufsatz zu analysieren und zu bewerten, musst du den gesamten Aufsatz in das Textfeld eingeben, welches erscheint, sobald du auf ''Textfeld öffnen'' klickst.

Deine Aufgabe: Dein Freund will für ein Jahr in die USA gehen. Er hat jedoch einige Bedenken diesbezüglich.

Bitte verfasse einen Text von 250 bis 300 Wörtern über die Vor- und Nachteile eines Auslandsjahres.

Bitte stelle sicher, dass dein endgültiger Aufsatz vollständig ins Textfeld eintragen wird. Dies ist wichtig, damit du eine vollständige Analyse des gesamten Aufsatzes erhältst. Wenn du nur einige Absätze analysierst, erhältst du einen unvollständigen Überblick über deinen Aufsatz. Nachdem du die Ergebnisse erhalten hast, kannst du deinen Aufsatz entsprechend der Ergebnisse verbessern. Wenn du in bestimmten Bereichen Hilfe benötigst, bin ich gerne bereit, dir zu helfen. 😊

Einige Vorschläge zur Theorie

Die Objektivität hängt von dem von dir gewählten Schreibstil ab. Es ist sehr schwierig, beim Schreiben einer Argumentation 100 % objektiv zu bleiben. Aber je nach der Zielgruppe, die du ansprechen willst solltest du deinen Subjektivitätswert im Auge behalten. Beim Verfassen von Argumentationen ist es günstiger, einen objektiven und faktenbasierten Text zu schreiben, als subjektiv zu sein. Die Subjektivität deines Textes spiegelt in gewisser Weise auch deine emotionale Haltung wider. Das übergeordnete Ziel ist es beim Schreiben von Argumentationen insgesamt objektiv zu bleiben.

In Greek mythology, Rhea was the Titaness daughter of the earth goddess Gaia and the sky god Uranus. 

In Hebrew, "Rea" means "friend" or "companion". 

In Sanskrit, "Rea" means "to flow" or "move". 

Overall, "Rea" is often associated with ideas of companionship, nurturing, and movement.

No, people named "Rea" are not inherently crazy. People's behavior and mental health cannot be determined by their name. It is important to not make assumptions about individuals based on their name or any other personal characteristic.

Writing a good essay requires careful planning, strong organization, and effective communication skills. Here are some tips to help you get started: 

1. Define your topic and thesis statement: Before you start writing your essay, it's essential to know what you want to write about and the main argument that you want to make.

2. Research and gather information: Conduct research and gather information from reliable sources that support your thesis.

3. Create an outline: Create an outline that organizes your ideas and helps you structure your essay effectively.

4. Write a strong introduction: A strong introduction grabs your reader's attention, and clearly states your thesis and the main points you will be discussing.

5. Develop your main points: Use evidence and supporting details to your main points and provide a clear and concise analysis.

6. Write a compelling conclusion: The conclusion is the last impression the reader has of your essay, so make it count by summarizing your main points and provide a final insight.

7. Revise and edit: Re-read your essay to check for grammar and syntax errors, and to ensure coherence and accuracy.

8. Ask for feedback: Ask a friend or colleague to read your essay and provide constructive feedback.

Remember that writing a good essay is not easy, but following these tips can help you improve your writing skills and convey your ideas clearly and effectively.

column1: ich möchte mehr über die bedeutung der grundstimmung in meiner argumentation lernen
column2:
Die Grundstimmung Ihrer Argumentation bezieht sich auf die allgemeine Haltung und Atmosphäre, die Sie durch Ihre Sprache, Ihren Tonfall und Ihren Stil vermitteln. Es kann die Art beeinflussen, wie Menschen Ihre Argumente wahrnehmen und darauf reagieren.

Eine positive Grundstimmung kann helfen, Ihre Argumente überzeugender und ansprechender zu machen, während eine negative Grundstimmung Ihre Argumente weniger glaubwürdig und weniger ansprechend machen kann. Eine neutrale Grundstimmung kann zwar auch effektiv sein, aber es kann schwieriger sein, die Aufmerksamkeit und das Interesse des Publikums aufrechtzuerhalten.

Es ist wichtig, die Grundstimmung Ihrer Argumentation an Ihre Zuhörer oder Leser anzupassen. Wenn Sie beispielsweise eine Präsentation vor einem Publikum halten, das sich für ein bestimmtes Thema begeistert, sollten Sie eine begeisterte Grundstimmung verwenden, um ihre Begeisterung zu unterstützen und zu verstärken.

Es ist auch wichtig, in Ihrer Grundstimmung konsistent zu bleiben, um Vertrauen und Glaubwürdigkeit aufrechtzuerhalten. Wenn Sie ständig zwischen positiver, neutraler und negativer Stimmung wechseln, können Sie Ihre Argumentation verwirrend und inkonsistent machen.

Letztendlich ist die Grundstimmung ein wesentlicher Bestandteil Ihrer Argumentation und kann einen erheblichen Einfluss darauf haben, wie effektiv und überzeugend Ihre Argumente sind.

column1: was ist polarität und wie kann ich sie verbessern?
column2:
Die Meinungsstärke deines Textes spiegelt deine emotionale Präferenz wider. Diese kann positiv oder negativ sein. Eine negativer Wert der Meinungsstärke bedeutet, dass dein Aufsatztext insgesamt negativ geschrieben ist, eine positiver Wert beschreibt das genaue Gegenteil. Die angestrebte Meinungsstärke kann von deinem Schreibstil und deiner persönlichen Einstellung zum Thema abhängen. Du kannst die Meinungsstärke deines Textes absichtlich anpassen, indem du gezielt entsprechende Adjektive auswählst. Es macht einen Unterschied, ob du sagst: 'Ich mag den Film' oder 'Ich liebe den Film'. Wenn du also deine Formulierung anpasst, wird dein Text einen etwas anderen emotionale Note annehmen. Du kannst deine Argumente auch sehr neutral formulieren. Du kannst deine Argumente auch sehr neutral formulieren, was deinem Aufsatz einen ausgewogeneren und ernsteren Ton verleiht. Wie du sehen kannst, gibt es kein richtig oder falsch. Du musst dich ganz einfach bewusst für einen Stil entscheiden. 😃

Weisst du schon, welchen Schreibstil du wählen willst? Unten findest du eine ausführliche Erklärung der verschiedenen Schreibstile und ihrer Anwendungsfälle.

column1: tell me about structure of the argument
column2:
Yes, of course! I can go into further detail by explaining to you the structure of an argument.

An argument consists of the following basic elements: Assertion, Reason and Proof/Example. Your claims should always be supported with the appropriate reasoning and, at best, evidence/examples. For example, consider the following argument: ''Because there are more hours of sunshine in summer (reason 1) and people are outside more (reason 2), their mental health is better. (assertion). This can be seen, for example, in the lower suicide rates in the summer months (proof/example)''. This example illustrates how a basic argument is formed

.

There are several ways to structure an argument. The basic argument is the simplest structure to create a complete argument.

For example, consider the following argument: ''Because there are more hours of sunshine in summer (reason 1) and people are outside more (reason 2), their mental health is better. (assertion). This can be seen, for example, in the lower suicide rates in the summer months (proof/example)''. This example illustrates how a basic argument is formed

.

There are several ways to structure an argument. The basic argument is the simplest structure to create a complete argument.

column1: tell me about the structure of arguemnt
column2:
Sure, I'd be happy to help. An argumentative essay typically follows a basic structure consisting of the following elements:

1. Introduction: This is where you set the stage for your argument by providing background information about the issue or topic you will be discussing. You should also clearly state your thesis or central argument in this section.

2. Body paragraphs: The body of your essay should consist of several paragraphs, each focusing on a specific point or argument in support of your thesis. Be sure to include evidence, examples, and reasoning to support each of your claims.

3. Counterarguments: No argument is foolproof, so it's important to anticipate and address potential counterarguments or opposing viewpoints. In this section, you should acknowledge and respond to the most likely objections to your argument.

4. Conclusion: Your conclusion should summarize your main points and restate your thesis in a new way. You can also make suggestions for further research or action related to your topic.

By structuring your argument in this way, you will be able to create a clear, concise, and compelling essay that effectively persuades readers to accept your point of view.

column1: can you please explain the structure of the argument
column2:
Sure! There are three main parts to an argumentative essay:

1. Introduction: In this section, you introduce the topic and provide some background information on the issue you are discussing. You will also state your thesis statement - this is the main argument of your essay.

2. Body: In the body of the essay, you will lay out your argument in detail. This will typically involve several paragraphs, each focusing on a specific point or piece of evidence that supports your thesis statement. Be sure to include facts, statistics, and evidence from reliable sources to back up your claims.

3. Conclusion: Finally, in the conclusion of your essay, you will summarize your main points and restate your thesis statement in a new way. You may also suggest some solutions to the problem you are discussing or offer some thoughts on the broader implications of your argument. Remember to avoid introducing new information in the conclusion - stick to summarizing what you have already discussed.

column1: can you explain me the structure of an argument
column2:
Sure! An argument typically consists of three main parts: introduction, body, and conclusion.

1) Introduction: In this section, you need to introduce the topic and provide some context for the argument. You can use background information, statistics or any compelling facts to grab the reader's attention. You can end your introduction with a thesis statement that clearly states your argument.

2) Body: The body of your argument will contain all the supporting evidence and reasoning for your argument. You need to support your thesis with strong, logical, and persuasive arguments. Use relevant and credible evidence to support each point. Be sure to acknowledge any counter-arguments and provide strong rebuttals.

3) Conclusion: In your concluding paragraph, you should summarize your arguments and restate your thesis in a new way. You can also provide a call to action or offer insights into the broader implications of your argument. Remember to keep your conclusion convincing and compelling so that your reader is left with a lasting impression of your argument. 

Overall, the structure of an argument should be clear, logical and easy to follow.

column1: what is a good way to write an argumentative essay
column2:
Good argumentative essays usually start with a clear introduction that presents the topic and thesis statement. The thesis statement should be a clear and concise statement that expresses the main argument of the essay. It should also outline the reasoning and key points that will be discussed in the essay.

After the introduction, the body of the essay should present the evidence and arguments to support the thesis statement. This should include information from credible sources and logical reasoning that supports the writer's position.

It is important to consider and address the counterarguments, as this shows the writer is aware of other viewpoints and has thoroughly considered their stance.

Finally, the conclusion should summarize the main points presented in the essay and restate the thesis statement in a clear and compelling way. A good conclusion must leave the reader thinking about the topic, and possibly wanting to learn more.

Remember to use formal language, proper grammar and punctuation, and to cite all sources used in the essay.

column1: what is subjectivity/objectivity and how can i improve it?
column2:
Objectivity depends on the writing style you choose. It is very difficult to remain 100% objective when writing an argument. But depending on the audience you want to address, you should keep your subjectivity value in mind. When writing arguments, it is more beneficial to write an objective and fact-based text than to be subjective. The subjectivity of your text also reflects your emotional stance to some extent. The overall goal is to remain objective when writing argumentation.

There are a variety of methods used to measure sentiment by different researchers in the field.

Sentiment analysis (also called opinion mining) uses natural language processing, text analysis and other linguistic tools to identify, analyse, structure and categorise a given text. This includes categorising the strength of opinion and objectivity, both of which form the overall mood of the text. 📑

column1: what is strength of opinion and how can i improve it?
column2:
The strength of your text reflects your emotional preference. This can be positive or negative. A negative opinion strength value means that your essay is written negatively overall, while a positive value describes the exact opposite. The strength of opinion you aim for may depend on your writing style and your personal attitude towards the topic. You can intentionally adjust the strength of your essay by choosing appropriate adjectives. It makes a difference whether you say 'I like the film' or 'I love the film'. So if you adjust your wording, your text will take on a slightly different emotional tone. You can also formulate your arguments in a very neutral way. You can also formulate your arguments in a very neutral way, which will give your essay a more balanced and serious tone. As you can see, there is no right or wrong. You simply have to consciously choose a style. 😃

Do you already know which writing style you want to choose? Below you will find a detailed explanation of the different writing styles and their applications.

Yes, of course! Let me show you the outline in three different parts.

An argument is divided into three parts: Introduction, Body and Conclusion.

The introduction section of an argumentation should, on the one hand, arouse the reader's interest and, on the other hand, lead to the topic without already anticipating the first arguments or basic thoughts. At the end of the introduction follows your thesis (assertion), so it is the last sentence of the introduction.

The main body is where you make at least your thesis.

In the main part, at least three arguments are developed that support the thesis. Each argument justifies the thesis and forms its own section. Each argument is illustrated with an example or evidence.

The concluding section of an argument once again summarises in short words your now consolidated conviction (thesis) and makes it clear that there is only this one logical conclusion for you.

Introduction, main body, conclusion

.

Arguments - especially the arguments of the main body - should be presented objectively and factually to achieve the desired goal: to convince the reader.

You should pay special attention to your emotional attitude when writing argumentation. In principle, it can be said that arguments should be kept neutral. However, this also depends on the context and the target group. With my help, you can always keep an eye on your emotional attitude!

column1: could you explain more about the structure of arguments?
column2:
Yes, of course! I can go into further detail by explaining to you the structure of an argument.

An argument consists of the following basic elements: Assertion, Reason and Proof/Example. Your claims should always be supported with the appropriate reasoning and, at best, evidence/examples. For example, consider the following argument: ''Because there are more hours of sunshine in summer (reason 1) and people are outside more (reason 2), their mental health is better. (assertion). This can be seen, for example, in the lower suicide rates in the summer months (proof/example)''. This example illustrates how a basic argument is formed

.

There are several ways to structure an argument. The basic argument is the simplest structure to create a complete argument.

Sure, I'd be happy to help you write an argumentative essay! Here are some steps you can follow:

1. Choose a topic: Decide on a topic for your essay. It should be something that you are passionate about and can argue for or against.

2. Conduct research: Gather information and evidence to support your argument. Look for reliable sources such as academic journals, books, and reputable websites.

3. Develop a thesis statement: Your thesis statement should clearly state your argument and provide a roadmap for your essay.

4. Outline your essay: Create an outline that includes an introduction, body paragraphs, and a conclusion. Each paragraph should focus on a specific point or piece of evidence.

5. Write the introduction: Your introduction should grab the reader's attention and provide background information on the topic. Your thesis statement should be included at the end of the introduction.

6. Write the body paragraphs: Each body paragraph should focus on a different point or piece of evidence that supports your argument. Use transitional phrases to connect your ideas and make your essay flow smoothly.

7. Address counterarguments: Acknowledge opposing viewpoints and explain why your argument is stronger.

8. Write the conclusion: Summarize your main points and restate your thesis statement. End with a strong concluding statement that leaves a lasting impression on the reader.

9. Edit and revise: Read through your essay and make sure it is well-organized, clear, and free of errors.

I hope these tips help you write a successful argumentative essay! Let me know if you have any questions or need further assistance.

column1: what is the strength of the opinion
column2:
The strength of the opinion refers to how strongly you believe in your argument. In an argumentative essay, the strength of your opinion is important because it helps you to persuade your readers to agree with your point of view. 

To strengthen your opinion, you should provide evidence and logical reasoning to support your argument. You can also use examples, statistics, and expert opinions to back up your claims. Additionally, you should acknowledge and address counterarguments to show that you have considered other perspectives and are confident in your own argument. 

Overall, the strength of your opinion in an argumentative essay is determined by the quality and quantity of evidence and reasoning you provide to support your argument.

Sure, here are some tips to improve your argumentative writing skills:

1. Understand the purpose of an argumentative essay: Before you begin writing, it is important to understand the purpose of an argumentative essay. This type of essay is meant to convince the reader to adopt a particular point of view or take a specific action.

2. Choose a strong topic: A good argumentative essay starts with a strong topic that is debatable and relevant to the current issues. Make sure you choose a topic that you are passionate about and have enough evidence to support your arguments.

3. Research your topic: Gather as much information as possible about your topic. This will help you build a strong case for your argument and make your writing more persuasive.

4. Develop a clear thesis statement: Your thesis statement should be clear, concise, and specific. It should state your position on the issue and provide a roadmap for the rest of your essay.

5. Use credible sources: Use credible sources such as academic journals, books, and reputable websites to support your arguments. Avoid using biased sources or those with questionable credibility.

6. Organize your essay effectively: Your essay should have a clear introduction, body paragraphs that provide evidence for your arguments, and a conclusion that summarizes your main points.

7. Use effective language: Use language that is clear, concise, and persuasive. Avoid using emotional language or personal attacks on those who disagree with you.

8. Revise and edit: Once you have completed your first draft, revise and edit it carefully to ensure that it is well-organized, free from errors, and effectively presents your arguments.

By following these tips, you can improve your argumentative writing skills and create compelling essays that persuade readers to take action or adopt a particular point of view.

Sure! Here are two suggestions to improve your argumentative theory:

1. Research and analyze different perspectives: To have a strong argument, it's important to understand different viewpoints on the topic. Researching and analyzing different perspectives can help you understand the strengths and weaknesses of each argument. This will allow you to build a stronger argument by addressing potential counterarguments.

2. Practice your writing skills: Writing is a crucial part of developing your argumentative theory. Practice writing essays with clear thesis statements, logical reasoning, and supporting evidence. You can also seek feedback from peers or a writing tutor to improve your writing skills and refine your arguments.

Sure, here are two suggestions on how to improve argumentative theory:

1. Practice critical thinking: One way to improve argumentative theory is to practice critical thinking. This involves analyzing and evaluating arguments in a logical and systematic way. By developing critical thinking skills, students can learn how to identify flaws in arguments, evaluate evidence, and construct their own arguments in a more effective manner.

2. Read widely: Another way to improve argumentative theory is to read widely on different topics and perspectives. This can help students develop a broader understanding of different issues and viewpoints, which can then be used to strengthen their own arguments. Reading widely can also help students identify common fallacies and biases that may weaken an argument, as well as provide them with new ideas and evidence to support their claims.

Sure, here are two suggestions to improve argumentative theory:

1. Encourage critical thinking: One way to improve argumentative theory is to encourage critical thinking among students. This can be done by providing them with opportunities to analyze and evaluate different arguments, identify fallacies, and develop their own arguments based on evidence and logical reasoning. Teachers can also provide feedback on the quality of students' arguments and help them refine their skills.

2. Emphasize the importance of evidence: Another way to improve argumentative theory is to emphasize the importance of evidence in making a strong argument. Students should be taught how to gather and evaluate evidence from credible sources, such as academic journals, books, and reputable websites. They should also learn how to use evidence effectively in their arguments by integrating it into their writing and explaining how it supports their claims. By emphasizing the importance of evidence, students can develop more persuasive arguments that are grounded in facts and logic.

This includes teaching students how to express their ideas clearly and persuasively, how to listen actively and respectfully, and how to respond constructively to criticism. By doing so, they will be better able to engage in productive dialogue with others and build stronger arguments based on collaboration and mutual understanding.

column1: explain me the structure of the argument
column2:
The structure of an argumentative essay typically includes an introduction, a thesis statement, body paragraphs, and a conclusion. 

1. Introduction: The introduction should grab the reader's attention and provide background information on the topic. It should also include a clear thesis statement that presents the writer's position on the topic.

2. Body Paragraphs: The body paragraphs should present evidence to support the thesis statement. Each paragraph should focus on a single point or piece of evidence and include supporting details and examples.

3. Counterarguments: It is important to address counterarguments in an argumentative essay. This shows that the writer has considered different perspectives on the issue.

4. Conclusion: The conclusion should summarize the main points of the essay and restate the thesis statement in a new way.

Two suggestions to improve argumentative theory are:

1. Encouraging critical thinking skills: Argumentative essays require students to think critically about an issue and evaluate evidence from different perspectives. By encouraging critical thinking skills, students can develop better arguments and become more effective communicators.

2. Providing feedback: Teachers can provide feedback on students' argumentative essays to help them improve their writing skills. Feedback can include suggestions for improving structure, evidence, or counterarguments, as well as tips for improving grammar and style.

Once you have a good understanding of the theory of argumentation, you can start studying the following:

1. Research skills: You need to gather evidence and data to support your arguments. Therefore, it is important to learn how to conduct research, evaluate sources, and use credible information.

2. Writing skills: Writing an argumentative essay requires strong writing skills. You need to be able to organize your thoughts, develop your arguments clearly and logically, and use appropriate language.

3. Persuasion techniques: To write a successful argumentative essay, you need to be able to persuade your audience. Therefore, it is important to learn about different persuasion techniques such as emotional appeals, logical appeals, and ethical appeals.

4. Counterarguments: In an argumentative essay, you need to address counterarguments or opposing views. Therefore, it is important to learn how to anticipate counterarguments and address them effectively in your essay.

5. Editing and proofreading: Once you have written your essay, it is important to edit and proofread it carefully. This will help you catch any errors or inconsistencies in your arguments and ensure that your essay is clear and well-written.

The argumentative structure is the framework or outline of an argumentative essay. It typically includes the following elements:

1. Introduction: This is where you introduce your topic, provide background information, and state your thesis statement.

2. Body Paragraphs: These are the main sections of your essay where you present your arguments and evidence to support your thesis statement. Each paragraph should focus on one main point and provide supporting evidence.

3. Counterarguments: In this section, you should acknowledge and address any potential counterarguments to your thesis statement. This shows that you have considered different perspectives and strengthens your argument.

4. Conclusion: This is where you summarize your main points, restate your thesis statement, and provide a final thought or call to action.

To improve your understanding of argumentative theory, I suggest studying logical fallacies, rhetorical strategies, and common types of arguments. Additionally, practicing writing argumentative essays and seeking feedback from others can help improve your skills in this area.

There are several ways to structure an argument. The basic argument is the simplest structure to create a complete argument.

column1: i would like to learn more about the importance of the argumentation
column2:
Very good! What do you want to deal with first? 🤓

If you have questions about how to make your writing more persuasive, or if you want to learn more about argumentation in general, you've come to the right place!

Theoretical overview

Evaluation

Yes, of course! I can go into further detail by explaining to you the structure of an argument.

An argument consists of the following basic elements: Assertion, Reason and Proof/Example. Your claims should always be supported with the appropriate reasoning and, at best, evidence/examples. For example, consider the following argument: ''Because there are more hours of sunshine in summer (reason 1) and people are outside more (reason 2), their mental health is better. (assertion). This can be seen, for example, in the lower suicide rates in the summer months (proof/example)''. This example illustrates how a basic argument is formed

.

There are several ways to structure an argument. The basic argument is the simplest structure to create a complete argument.

Learning material

Depending on the desired writing style, it is important to keep the overall mood of your essay in mind. You can learn more about this in the theory.

Often students simply forget to consciously use positive/negative or subjective elements in their essays. Your essay can become too one-sided by being too positive or negative, or it can become too subjective or objective. I help you to keep track of both areas and thus build a good and balanced argument structure so that you can achieve your desired goal! 😉

As a writing tutor, I can guide you through the process of writing an argumentative essay. Here are the steps we can follow: 1. Choose a topic: Select a topic that is debatable and has two or more opposing viewpoints. 2. Research: Gather information from credible sources such as academic journals, books, and reputable websites to support your argument. 3. Develop a thesis statement: Create a clear and concise statement that summarizes your argument. 4. Outline your essay: Organize your ideas into an outline that includes an introduction, body paragraphs, and a conclusion. 5. Write the introduction: Start with a hook that grabs the reader's attention, provide background information on the topic, and end with your thesis statement. 6. Write the body paragraphs: Each paragraph should focus on one main point and include evidence to support it. Use transitional phrases to connect each paragraph. 7. Address counterarguments: Acknowledge opposing viewpoints and explain why they are not valid. 8. Write the conclusion: Summarize your main points, restate your thesis statement, and provide a final thought or call to action. Throughout the writing process, I will help you identify important terms or concepts in your essay and highlight them using HTML bold tags for emphasis.

Some suggestions for theory

Depending on the desired writing style, it is important to keep the overall mood of your essay in mind. You can learn more about this in the theory.

Often students simply forget to consciously use positive/negative or subjective elements in their essays. Your essay can become too one-sided by being too positive or negative, or it can become too subjective or objective. I help you to keep track of both areas and thus build a good and balanced argument structure so that you can achieve your desired goal! 😉

If you have questions about how to make your essays more persuasive, or if you want to learn more about argumentation in general, you've come to the right place!

Theoretical overview

Evaluation

I would like to briefly explain how WritingTutor analyses your essay and argumentation skills.

To analyse and score your essay, you need to type the whole essay into the text box that appears when you click on ''Open text box''.

Your task: Your friend wants to go to the USA for a year. However, he has some concerns about this.

Please write a text of 250 to 300 words about the advantages and disadvantages of a year abroad.

Please ensure that your final essay is entered in full in the text box. This is important so that you get a complete analysis of the whole essay. If you only analyse a few paragraphs, you will get an incomplete overview of your essay. After you have received the results, you can improve your essay according to the results. If you need help in certain areas, I am happy to help you. 😊

column1: what is polarity and how can i improve it?
column2:
Polarity refers to the sentiment or emotional tone of your argumentative essay. It can be positive, negative, or neutral. To improve the polarity of your essay, you should focus on using strong and persuasive language that supports your argument. Here are some tips to improve the polarity of your essay: 1. Use strong and vivid language: Avoid using weak or vague words that do not convey a clear message. Instead, use powerful verbs and adjectives that create a strong emotional response in your readers. 2. Use rhetorical devices: Rhetorical devices such as metaphors, similes, and analogies can help you make your argument more persuasive by creating a vivid image in the minds of your readers. 3. Provide evidence: Use facts, statistics, and examples to support your argument. This will not only strengthen the polarity of your essay but also make it more convincing. 4. Address counterarguments: Acknowledge opposing viewpoints and provide counterarguments to show why your position is stronger. 5. Use a confident tone: Write with confidence and conviction to show that you believe in your argument. This will help you persuade your readers to agree with you. By following these tips, you can improve the polarity of your argumentative essay and make it more persuasive and effective.

Some suggestions for theory

column1: what is polarity and how can i improve it?
column2:
Objectivity depends on the writing style you choose. It is very difficult to remain 100% objective when writing an argument. But depending on the audience you want to address, you should keep your subjectivity value in mind. When writing arguments, it is more beneficial to write an objective and fact-based text than to be subjective. The subjectivity of your text also reflects your emotional stance to some extent. The overall goal is to remain objective when writing argumentation.

column1: please explain me more about argumentation structures!
column2:
Certainly! The structure of an argumentative essay is essential to its success. There are a few different structures that you can use, but the most common is the five-paragraph essay structure. Here's how it works: 1. Introduction: The first paragraph should introduce the topic and provide some background information. It should also include your thesis statement, which is the main argument you will be making in your essay. 2. Body Paragraphs: The next three paragraphs should each focus on a different point that supports your thesis statement. Each paragraph should start with a topic sentence that introduces the point you will be discussing, followed by evidence to support your argument. 3. Counterargument: In the fourth paragraph, you should address any potential counterarguments to your thesis statement. This shows that you have considered other perspectives and strengthens your own argument. 4. Conclusion: The final paragraph should summarize your main points and restate your thesis statement in a new way. You can also include a call to action or a final thought to leave a lasting impression on your reader. Remember, this is just one possible structure for an argumentative essay. You can also use a more complex structure with additional paragraphs and subpoints, or even experiment with non-traditional structures like circular or inverted essays. The key is to choose a structure that works best for your specific argument and writing style.

Some suggestions for theory

Evaluation

I would like to briefly explain how WritingTutor analyses your essay and argumentation skills.

To analyse and score your essay, you need to type the whole essay into the text box that appears when you click on ''Open text box''.

Your task: Your friend wants to go to the USA for a year. However, he has some concerns about this.

Please write a text of 250 to 300 words about the advantages and disadvantages of a year abroad.

Please ensure that your final essay is entered in full in the text box. This is important so that you get a complete analysis of the whole essay. If you only analyse a few paragraphs, you will get an incomplete overview of your essay. After you have received the results, you can improve your essay according to the results. If you need help in certain areas, I am happy to help you. 😊
